title: Farage on Reform's candidate controversies and immigration policy
content:
Nigel Farage was asked on BBC Question Time about the selection of candidates for his party who have been widely reported for their controversial comments.
Mr Farage says "in most cases they've been disowned", and he "wouldn't want anything to do with them".
A Channel 4 documentary recorded a Reform UK campaigner using a racist term about the Conservative leader Rishi Sunak.
Mr Farage also spoke about the role of immigration in the UK, saying it should be the "biggest issue" in the upcoming general election.
A pair of eagles have taken a break from breeding to care for their injured chick, leaving experts amazed.
Players can meet Clive Myrie, Laura Kuenssberg and Jeremy Vine whilst helping Larry the Cat find ballot boxes across the game.
The mesmerising moment was captured in Ullapool harbour by Noel Hawkins earlier this week.
A signed summary of BBC Newsline.
Dash cam footage shows objects being thrown at a police car from a fast moving van.
Aid worker explains how his career helped him come to terms with his own terminal cancer diagnosis.
Watch the latest news summary from BBC World News. International news updated 24 hours a day.
A Highland mother has said her life has been transformed by CrossFit after grabbing a place in the finals of the sports annual adaptive games in Texas. 
A garden has been created at Hampton Court Palace to celebrate 25 years of The Lion King in London.
Europe’s tallest active volcano roared as it spewed lava from one of its largest craters.
Low humidity, gusty winds, and a dangerous heatwave are exacerbating fire risks in the northern part of the state.
The latest weather forecast for the East of England from BBC Look East.
King and Queen attend Thistle service in Edinburgh
Filmed in one of Belfast's most deprived areas, The Flats shines a light on post-conflict Northern Ireland.
CCTV footages shows Woodward ramming into another motorist who tried to overtake him on the A55.
Pupils at two Stoke-on-Trent schools share their policy priorities.
A primary school in Chad is providing an opportunity for thousands of Sudanese refugees to resume learning.
At least 121 people, mostly women, were killed in the crush at a religious event in northern India.
Jeremie Tronet tells the BBC about the devastating destruction of the storm on the island where he has lived for 15 years.

The whale was spotted as the schoolchildren were returning from a trip to Sark.
